content.webTitle: The truth hurts – Harold Thomas wins award with Aboriginal art that is raw and real

fields.headline: The truth hurts – Harold Thomas wins award with Aboriginal art that is raw and real
fields.bodyText: A baby is wrenched from its mother, mouth still suckling on her nipple. Pushed down into the dirt on her knees, with her face twisted in both anguish and rage, the woman bites down on the finger of a policeman who tries to restrain her, and grabs at another infant with her left hand. A boy sits in the red desert over a still body, with so much pain in his face you want to turn away. There’s a nun behind them, standing ready to cover the naked baby in a white cloth as it’s torn away. Titled Tribal Abduction, the winner of the 33rd Telstra National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Awards (NATSIAAs) is a striking choice – large in scale, deeply political and deeply confronting. It hangs with 74 finalists at the Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory, where it hits home particularly hard: the NT is still reverberating from last week’s Four Corners, and the shocking images and footage of black children being abused in government care. “[The painting] will be confronting for some people but it’s a reality, it is our history, it is our legacy,” says Indigenous curator Kimberley Moulton, a member of the three-person judging panel. “It’s a trauma that a lot of us still carry.” As the artist Harold Joseph Thomas (Bundoo) says, “It’s been happening for 200 years ... This keeps going.” Thomas knows well the power an image can hold. A Darwin local, and a descendant of the Luritja and Wambai people of central Australia, he was just 24 and fresh out of art school when he put together the three blocks of colour – red, yellow and black – that would become the Australian Aboriginal flag. Originally designed for the land rights movement in 1971, the flag and its colours are now an iconic symbol of Indigenous Australia: flown at the Aboriginal tent embassy in 1972; carried by Cathy Freeman at the 1994 Commonwealth Games; and granted Flag of Australia status the following year. He puts the success of that one striking image down to its simplicity. “If you want to get an image that portrays a symbol for everybody you can’t use secular objects,” he says. “You’ve got to broaden it, abstract it, and then you’ve got to make it linear and clear. And it’s the metaphor in it, it’s the lyric, the image of the land – there’s Aboriginal language in that [flag].” But after four decades as an artist, Thomas has become more well known for his landscape and nature paintings. A figurative work drawing from European inspirations including Delacroix, Caravaggio and Degas, Tribal Abduction represents a significant departure. “I’ve decided that now, I must do this,” he tells Guardian Australia. He sees this type of work as an artistic challenge. “[Painting the body] is a turning point, about me proving to myself that I’m an artist.” The subject matter of his winning painting is as personal as it is political. Both of Thomas’s parents were removed from their families in the 1920s, and Thomas was seven when he was taken from them, sent to an Anglican institution for Aboriginal boys. Born in a segregated community, his grandmother would sneak in at night to cuddle her grandchildren. “I remember her chewing tobacco, bush tobacco, it has a beautiful aroma – it’s called pituri. The smoke that was on her, and the lovely smell of her body when she hugged me – I will remember that all my life.” He remembers his removal too. “It was awful,” he says. “[The trauma] lasts a long time, but you’ve got to move on. A lot of people don’t. I’ve moved on, because I am able to express it. But I can understand those who haven’t.” The finalists and category winners of the NATSIAAs were selected by a judging panel consisting of Moulton, contemporary Indigenous artist Vernon Ah Kee, and artist and philanthropist Don Whyte. The judges were looking for a multifaceted exhibition of contemporary paintings, 3D work and multimedia, alongside more traditional Indigenous art; a varied collection that’s at odds, the judges say, with the limited way Australia and the wider world perceives Indigenous art. There’s the steel work of Gunybi Ganambarr; the bold shapes and colours of Naomi Hobson; the humour of Vincent Namatjira, who has painted the Queen and Prince Philip attending the exhibition, “a bit nervous and excited at seeing so many great paintings”; the Youth Award-winning multimedia work of Yolngu director Ishmael Marika; and a piece by Nicole Monks, the first performance artist ever selected as a NATSIAA finalist. There’s the field painting of Betty Kuntiwa Pumani, who has won the Work on Paper Award for the fourth consecutive year, with the striking red and white mapping of her native land and its stories. And there’s the European influence of the winner Harold Thomas, who at the ceremony acknowledged that his style often put him at odds with the Aboriginal art world: “Even though my art is very western, the elements of it reflect my place, which is Aboriginal, and the land tells me so.” “Aboriginal art is so often relegated to the decorative arts or the primitive, and with good reason: because it’s been consistently described like that for decades,” judge and artist Ah Kee tells Guardian Australia. “I was looking for those pieces that would encourage people to ascribe different descriptors to this show, and to who we are [as Indigenous artists] – more than just blackfellas in the desert.” Coulton agrees; Aboriginal art is often positioned as either traditional painting about country “within the ‘noble savage’ space”, she says, or as political art. “We’re siloed in these spaces. It is really limiting, and it’s not a true representation of what we’re doing.” Ah Kee speaks of the Indigenous artists who declare themselves apolitical, too. “You see that all the time,” he says. “It disappoints me, but they are part and parcel of what Aboriginal art is.” Consistently political in his art and in his commentary, Ah Kee has long been outspoken about Indigenous artists who play into what he sees as comfortable, often idealised notions about the life they are living, and the palatable art they should be producing. “I want us all to be politically aware of how we’re positioned in society. We have no choice as Aboriginal people,” he says. “But a lot of Aboriginal artists, they don’t want to be seen as political, and they go out of their way to declare that. “There’s lots of reasons for that – mostly it’s because they want to eat ... [But their art] makes people who spend money on it feel good about themselves, without having to think about the reality of those people’s lives.” The winning painting by Harold Thomas doesn’t come with that option: it’s raw, it’s urgent, and it’s undeniable. And like much of the art on show at the NATSIAAs, it keeps a story alive. “There are no Aboriginal people who are going to turn up to this exhibition, look at the work, and not know what it’s talking about,” Ah Kee says. “Not everyone will like it – not many people will like it, actually. It’s a hard subject matter, and the fact that it’s so autobiographical really hits a nerve for the country.” He explains: “When whitefellas paint work about themselves, everyone claps them. But when blackfellas do it ...” he trails off. “I’d like to see that work acquired by the National Portrait Gallery, but it won’t be. I’d like to see it acquired by the prime minister and cabinet, but it won’t be. Whereas you get somebody like Brett Whiteley making paintings about Sydney, and he’s called a ‘quintessential Australian’. Well actually, maybe he’s not the best example of a quintessential Australian. “Selecting [Thomas] as a winner strengthens the award, and adds to its legacy I think. 2016 will be the year that Harold won for this entry. And hats off to him.” 2016’s NATSIAAs will also be remembered as the first year a performance artist won in the 3D category. Nicole Monks is a Sydney-based artist from a mixed Aboriginal, Dutch and English heritage – “So: first nations, first people to come on a boat and go, ‘Hey, there’s a country down there’, and first people to come and colonise it,” she explains. “How do you live with all those things together? And how does that feel?” In her work We Are All Animals, Monks has married the fur of a sheep with the feathers of an emu to create a new animal that represents her own inner conflict: part native, part introduced species. She wears the costume, dancing and nesting in various surrounds, before removing it, naked and exhausted. Wherever you end up, you have to make a home, she says – but it’s not always easy. Monks discovered her Indigenous heritage only nine years ago, after hunting down the paperwork that proved the ancestry of her grandmother: a pale-skinned member of the stolen generations, who grew up in an orphanage. After a life filled with an indefinable tension – she describes it as one between the head and the heart – the discovery didn’t come as a shock. “It was actually a relief. Like, ‘Oh, thank god. That’s why [I feel like this],” she says. “So I went back to WA for the first time as an adult, to tell my uncles and cousins and everyone – these people I’d never met – that they were Aboriginal too.” She wanted to make a work about what it feels like straddling two worlds. “All this learnt behaviour in the head – so, the introduced western species [of the sheep], up the top. And then the native feeling from here,” she gestures to her chest. “What I wanted to do was create a whole new animal that embodied those things ... and to show everyone that we are just animals. We’re trying so hard to push ourselves out of that animal kingdom, as though we’re above it somehow. We’re not.” As for the exhibition as a whole, Ah Kee is hesitant to limit it by describing the work – or the industry it represents – in any one way. “People are just finding their voice,” he says. “I think we’re just heating up.” • Telstra NATSIAA finalists’ works will be exhibited at the MAGNT from Saturday 6 August until Sunday 30 October, 2016. The Salon des Refusés is on at the Charles Darwin University Art Gallery until 30 September; the Darwin Aboriginal Art fair is on until August 7 at the Darwin Convention Centre. Guardian Australia was a guest of Telstra NATSIAA
